question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and harms of adopting reduced tillage systems on European farms?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple European countries, reduced or non-inversion tillage has been associated with: increased biomass, species richness or abundance of earthworms; greater abundance of some non-earthworm invertebrates; more weeds and/or weed species; higher Eurasian skylark nest density, earlier laying, shorter foraging distances; and greater abundance of some birds (including skylark, seed-eating songbirds and gamebirds) in late winter; a review also reported that no-till systems had more invertebrate bird food resources (all from Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Hungary, Ireland, Lithuania, the Netherlands, Slovakia, Switzerland and the UK) [126]. Other documented outcomes include more soil microbes, more earthworm species, and higher microbial activity under reduced tillage in some trials, with other trials finding mixed or no effects on microbes, earthworms or other soil fauna [906]. Soil outcomes reported include reduced compaction and runoff under controlled traffic and reduced tillage in some studies, but higher compaction under reduced tillage in others [906]; reduced soil loss and runoff under reduced tillage in several trials, but increased soil loss under no-till when there was no crop cover [906]; generally higher soil organic carbon under no/reduced tillage across many studies, alongside a randomized replicated trial from Spain finding greater soil organic carbon under conventional tillage and another trial finding no effect [906]; maintained or increased soil organic matter and improved soil structure, and higher nutrient retention in several studies, with mixed effects on soil nitrogen and one trial reporting less carbon and nitrate in no-till soil though conventionally tilled soil lost more of both [906]. Reported harms or neutral effects include negative, no, or inconsistent effects on some invertebrates (including earthworms), plant seed species numbers, some weed species, mammals, and some birds; one study found bird preferences for conservation tillage fields decreased over time; long-term earthworm responses were mixed across two 10-year studies; weed responses varied by crop type [126]. Yield effects reported include no yield difference in a randomized, replicated study from Portugal, while other non-European trials reported both lower and higher yields under different conditions [906].
summary_statements: Across multiple European countries, reduced or non-inversion tillage has been associated with increased biomass, species richness or abundance of earthworms.
Reduced or non-inversion tillage has been associated with a greater abundance of some non-earthworm invertebrates.
Reduced or non-inversion tillage has been associated with more weeds and/or weed species.
Reduced or non-inversion tillage has been associated with higher Eurasian skylark nest density, earlier laying, and shorter foraging distances.
Reduced or non-inversion tillage has been associated with a greater abundance of some birds, including skylarks, seed-eating songbirds, and gamebirds, in late winter.
A review reported that no-till systems had more invertebrate bird food resources.
Some trials show more soil microbes, more earthworm species, and higher microbial activity under reduced tillage.
Other trials found that reduced tillage had mixed or no effects on microbes, earthworms, or other soil fauna.
Some studies reported reduced soil compaction and runoff when using controlled traffic and reduced tillage.
Other studies reported higher soil compaction under reduced tillage.
Several trials showed reduced soil loss and runoff under reduced tillage systems.
Increased soil loss was observed under no-till systems when there was no crop cover.
Many studies found that soil organic carbon was generally higher under no-till or reduced tillage.
A randomized replicated trial from Spain found greater soil organic carbon under conventional tillage.
Another trial found no effect on soil organic carbon from different tillage systems.
Several studies found that reduced tillage maintained or increased soil organic matter and improved soil structure.
Several studies found higher nutrient retention with reduced tillage.
Effects of reduced tillage on soil nitrogen have been mixed.
One trial reported less carbon and nitrate in no-till soil, although conventionally tilled soil lost more of both.
Reduced tillage systems have shown negative, no, or inconsistent effects on some invertebrates, including earthworms.
Reduced tillage systems have shown negative, no, or inconsistent effects on plant seed species numbers, some weed species, mammals, and some birds.
One study found that bird preferences for conservation tillage fields decreased over time.
The long-term responses of earthworms to reduced tillage were mixed across two 10-year studies.
Weed responses to reduced tillage varied by crop type.
A randomized, replicated study from Portugal found no yield difference between tillage systems.
Non-European trials have reported both lower and higher crop yields under different conditions with reduced tillage.

question_details.query: How do the effects of growing cover crops between crop rows compare to growing them when a field is empty?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Between crop rows in perennial systems (orchards/vineyards), ground cover generally produced similar grape yields in several trials, though some trials reported lower yields; effects on other perennial crops were mixed, with higher chestnut yields under resident vegetation but lower avocado yields under seeded grasses/legumes (ID: 1352). In these inter-row settings, biodiversity responses included more birds and higher bird diversity with resident vegetation versus bare, tilled row-middles, and more mushrooms and mushroom species with cover crops without tillage (ID: 2333; ID: 1413). In arable systems when fields were empty (winter/off-season), cover crops sometimes reduced weed numbers and weed species richness, sometimes increased weeds, and sometimes had no effect compared to no cover or winter fallow; weed community composition also differed (ID: 1394). Off-season cover crops produced mixed pest and disease outcomes compared to winter fallow or no cover: lettuces were less severely diseased in some comparisons, broccoli and tomato seedling disease was often similar, and tomato damage differences were inconsistent; numbers of other pests (e.g., mites, leafminers, nematodes) and soil fungi also showed mixed or no consistent differences (ID: 1394). Within arable crops using living mulches between crop rows, some comparisons found fewer aphids but also fewer parasitized aphids relative to no cover (ID: 1394).
summary_statements: In perennial systems like orchards and vineyards, ground cover grown between crop rows generally produced similar grape yields in several trials.
Some trials in perennial systems reported lower grape yields when ground cover was grown between crop rows.
The effects of growing ground cover on perennial crops other than grapes were mixed.
Chestnut yields were higher when resident vegetation was grown between crop rows.
Avocado yields were lower when seeded grasses or legumes were grown between crop rows.
In inter-row settings, resident vegetation resulted in more birds and higher bird diversity compared to bare, tilled row-middles.
In inter-row settings, using cover crops without tillage resulted in more mushrooms and more mushroom species.
In arable systems, cover crops grown when fields were empty sometimes reduced weed numbers and weed species richness compared to no cover or winter fallow.
In arable systems, cover crops grown when fields were empty sometimes increased weeds compared to no cover or winter fallow.
In arable systems, cover crops grown when fields were empty sometimes had no effect on weeds compared to no cover or winter fallow.
The composition of the weed community also differed when off-season cover crops were used compared to having no cover or winter fallow.
Off-season cover crops produced mixed pest and disease outcomes compared to winter fallow or no cover.
Lettuces were less severely diseased in some comparisons when grown after off-season cover crops.
Broccoli and tomato seedling disease was often similar between fields with off-season cover crops and those with winter fallow or no cover.
Differences in tomato damage were inconsistent when comparing fields with off-season cover crops to those without.
The numbers of pests like mites, leafminers, and nematodes showed mixed or no consistent differences when using off-season cover crops.
The numbers of soil fungi also showed mixed or no consistent differences when using off-season cover crops.
Within arable crops using living mulches between crop rows, some comparisons found fewer aphids relative to having no cover.
Within arable crops using living mulches between crop rows, some comparisons also found fewer parasitized aphids relative to having no cover.

question_details.query: What are the comparative effects of using green manures versus cover crops on soil organic carbon and crop yield?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Cover crops: A replicated study from Denmark and a review based mainly in Japan found increased soil carbon under cover crops, with one study reporting further increases when legumes were included in the cover crop mix [898]. One replicated USA trial found higher tomato yield from soils previously under a ryegrass cover crop [898]. Green manures: Two controlled, randomized, replicated studies from India and Pakistan found higher soil organic carbon or increased grain yields when green manures were grown [908].
summary_statements: A replicated study from Denmark and a review based mainly in Japan found increased soil carbon under cover crops.
One study reported further increases in soil carbon when legumes were included in the cover crop mix.
One replicated USA trial found higher tomato yield from soils previously under a ryegrass cover crop.
Two controlled, randomized, replicated studies from India and Pakistan found higher soil organic carbon or increased grain yields when green manures were grown.

question_details.query: What are the benefits and drawbacks of different tillage practices on sandy loam soils in Europe?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies including Europe and soils such as sandy loam, reduced or no-tillage often increased soil organic carbon compared to conventional tillage, with several studies and reviews reporting higher carbon under no/reduced tillage, though one randomized, replicated trial in Spain found greater carbon under conventional tillage and one Canadian trial found no effect (906). Reduced tillage frequently maintained or increased soil organic matter and improved soil structure, with some studies finding higher nutrient retention; however, one controlled, replicated trial found less carbon and nitrate in no-till (while conventionally tilled soil lost more) and effects on soil nitrogen were mixed (906). For erosion, multiple replicated trials (including in Europe) showed reduced soil loss and runoff under reduced tillage, but no-tillage increased soil loss when crop cover was absent; delaying ploughing until spring in Denmark and Norway reduced soil loss and nitrate leaching (906, 712). Regarding soil water and drought-related properties, conventional ploughing and sub-soiling decreased soil crack size and increased infiltration and water content in replicated European and Indian trials (906). Compaction responses were mixed: some trials found reduced compaction under controlled traffic and reduced tillage, while others found higher compaction under reduced tillage (906). Yield responses varied: one Canadian study reported lower yields under minimum/no-tillage, a U.S. study found higher yields with subsoiling, and a Portuguese study found no yield effect of tillage treatment (906). SOIL TYPES COVERED include sandy loam among others (906).
summary_statements: In studies including Europe and sandy loam soils, reduced or no-tillage often increased soil organic carbon compared to conventional tillage.
Several studies and reviews reported higher carbon under no-tillage or reduced tillage.
One randomized, replicated trial in Spain found greater carbon under conventional tillage.
One Canadian trial found no effect of tillage on soil organic carbon.
Reduced tillage frequently maintained or increased soil organic matter.
Reduced tillage frequently improved soil structure.
Some studies found higher nutrient retention with reduced tillage.
One controlled, replicated trial found less carbon and nitrate in no-till soil, while conventionally tilled soil lost more.
The effects of different tillage practices on soil nitrogen were mixed.
Multiple replicated trials, including some in Europe, showed reduced soil loss and runoff under reduced tillage.
No-tillage increased soil loss when crop cover was absent.
Delaying ploughing until spring in Denmark and Norway reduced soil loss and nitrate leaching.
In replicated European and Indian trials, conventional ploughing and sub-soiling decreased soil crack size.
In replicated European and Indian trials, conventional ploughing and sub-soiling increased infiltration and water content.
Soil compaction responses to different tillage practices were mixed.
Some trials found reduced compaction under controlled traffic and reduced tillage.
Other trials found higher compaction under reduced tillage.
Yield responses to different tillage practices varied.
One Canadian study reported lower yields under minimum or no-tillage.
A U.S. study found higher yields with subsoiling.
A Portuguese study found no yield effect from the tillage treatment.
The soil types covered in the relevant studies include sandy loam among others.

question_details.query: What evidence exists from studies in the USA regarding the impact of cover crops and crop residue management on crop yields?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Cover crops: Across replicated, controlled studies conducted in the USA, cash crop yields with winter cover crops were sometimes lower than without cover crops in some comparisons, sometimes higher in some comparisons, sometimes showed no difference, and sometimes showed inconsistent differences; one USA study on summer cover crops reported inconsistent yield differences. USA studies also reported higher cash crop yields when winter cover crops were legumes versus nonâ€‘legumes, and when mixtures of legumes and grasses were used versus legumes alone [1351]. Crop residue management: In the action on retaining crop residues, yield effects were reported from Australia and China (higher yields with residue retention in some trials), while a USA study in that action addressed soil erosion rather than yield, so USA yield impacts were not reported in that evidence set [907].
summary_statements: Across replicated, controlled studies conducted in the USA, cash crop yields with winter cover crops were sometimes lower than without cover crops in some comparisons.
In some comparisons from USA studies, cash crop yields with winter cover crops were higher than without cover crops.
Some USA studies showed no difference in cash crop yields with winter cover crops compared to without.
Some USA studies showed inconsistent differences in cash crop yields with winter cover crops.
One USA study on summer cover crops reported inconsistent yield differences.
USA studies reported higher cash crop yields when winter cover crops were legumes versus non-legumes.
USA studies reported higher cash crop yields when mixtures of legumes and grasses were used as winter cover crops versus when legumes were used alone.
In the action on retaining crop residues, yield effects were reported from Australia and China.
A USA study on retaining crop residues addressed soil erosion rather than yield.
USA yield impacts from retaining crop residues were not reported in the evidence set.

question_details.query: What is the available evidence on how incorporating grass or pasture into arable systems affects soil nutrients?

summary_details.relevant_summary: A replicated study from Denmark reported that, within leys in crop rotations on sandy-loam soil, reducing the extent of grass pasture decreased undesirable nitrogen uptake by grasses and consequently required lower fertilizer rates for subsequent crops [900].
summary_statements: Within leys in crop rotations on sandy-loam soil, reducing the extent of grass pasture decreased undesirable nitrogen uptake by grasses.
Reducing the extent of grass pasture within leys in crop rotations on sandy-loam soil required lower fertilizer rates for subsequent crops.

question_details.query: What actions can be taken on European farms with sandy-loam soils to improve soil structure?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Amend soil with fresh plant material or crop remains: studies reported improved soil structure when straw was incorporated, larger soil aggregates, increased soil organic carbon, and reduced soil loss, with soils covered including sandy loam [910].
- Add mulch to crops: trials showed mulch increased soil stability, reduced erosion and runoff, and one trial reported mulch improved soil structure and increased soil organic matter; soils covered include sandy loam and gravelly sandy loam [887].
- Control traffic and traffic timing: evidence from Europe and Australia found more soil pores, less compaction, reduced runoff, and increased water infiltration under controlled traffic; soils covered include sandy loam [899].
- Amend soil with manures and agricultural composts: studies found larger soil aggregations and positive effects on soil physical properties, as well as higher soil organic matter and carbon; soils covered include sandy loam [911].
summary_statements: Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains can improve soil structure.
Studies reported improved soil structure when straw was incorporated into the soil.
Incorporating straw into soil resulted in larger soil aggregates and increased soil organic carbon.
Incorporating straw into soil resulted in reduced soil loss.
Adding mulch to crops can increase soil stability.
Adding mulch to crops can reduce erosion and runoff.
One trial reported that mulch improved soil structure and increased soil organic matter.
Controlling traffic and traffic timing on soil can result in more soil pores and less compaction.
Controlled traffic on soil can lead to reduced runoff and increased water infiltration.
Amending soil with manures and agricultural composts can result in larger soil aggregations.
Amending soil with manures and agricultural composts can have positive effects on soil physical properties.
Amending soil with manures and agricultural composts can result in higher soil organic matter and carbon.

question_details.query: Which are the most consistently beneficial actions for increasing microbial biomass in soil?
What are the effects of incorporating leys or grasslands into arable farming systems in Europe?

summary_details.relevant_summary: A replicated study from Denmark reported that reducing the extent of grass pasture within leys reduced undesirable nitrogen uptake by grasses and therefore required lower fertilizer application rates for subsequent crops on sandy-loam soil (900). A controlled study in Finland found that clover leys had higher spider abundance and fewer pest insects than a barley control (643). A UK study found that one-year leys had significantly lower earthworm species richness and abundance than three-and-a-half-year leys (643). A replicated UK study found that grass leys supported fewer plant species than nine other conservation measures (643). Across seven studies (four replicated, two also controlled) reverting arable land to permanent grassland showed no clear benefit to wildlife, including UK birds in winter and summer, wading birds in Denmark, grey partridges, brown hares in the UK, and plants in the Czech Republic; one controlled before-and-after UK study found grey partridge numbers fell significantly following reversion (561). Similarly, five studies assessing reversion to permanent grassland found no clear benefit to birds, with one controlled before-and-after UK study reporting a significant decline in grey partridge numbers after reversion (210).
summary_statements: A replicated study from Denmark reported that reducing the extent of grass pasture within leys reduced undesirable nitrogen uptake by grasses.
Reducing the extent of grass pasture within leys required lower fertilizer application rates for subsequent crops on sandy-loam soil.
A controlled study in Finland found that clover leys had a higher abundance of spiders than a barley control.
A controlled study in Finland found that clover leys had fewer pest insects than a barley control.
A UK study found that one-year leys had significantly lower earthworm species richness than three-and-a-half-year leys.
A UK study found that one-year leys had significantly lower earthworm abundance than three-and-a-half-year leys.
A replicated UK study found that grass leys supported fewer plant species than nine other conservation measures.
Reverting arable land to permanent grassland showed no clear benefit to wildlife, including UK birds, wading birds in Denmark, grey partridges, brown hares, and plants in the Czech Republic.
One controlled before-and-after UK study found grey partridge numbers fell significantly following the reversion of arable land to permanent grassland.
Five studies assessing the reversion of arable land to permanent grassland found no clear benefit to birds.
A controlled before-and-after UK study reported a significant decline in grey partridge numbers after the reversion of arable land to permanent grassland.

question_details.query: How do the effects of amending soil with fresh plant material compare to retaining crop residues in the field?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains has been reported to increase microbial biomass, improve soil structure in at least one study, reduce soil loss in one case (with mixed erosion results elsewhere), raise soil nitrogen and sometimes reduce nitrate leaching, consistently increase soil organic carbon across multiple studies (with larger aggregates in one case), and raise yields in some trials, including higher barley yield and higher grain yield with earlier-season incorporation [910]. Retaining crop residues has been reported to increase microbial biomass, reduce water runoff, increase water storage, reduce soil erosion, show mixed effects on soil physical properties in one comparison, increase soil organic carbon and nitrogen (sometimes only with fertilizer), and raise yields in trials (sometimes only with fertilizer and no-tillage) [907]. Incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals has shown reductions in weed growth in some studies, variable or short-lived weed control in others, mixed effects on pests, possible inhibition of crop growth that can be mitigated by timing, and mixed effects on yield depending on controls and crop, with one study noting increased profit versus unweeded controls but not versus weeded controls [728].
summary_statements: Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains has been reported to increase microbial biomass.
Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains has been reported to improve soil structure.
Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains has been reported to reduce soil loss, though erosion results have been mixed.
Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains can raise soil nitrogen.
Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains can sometimes reduce nitrate leaching.
Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains consistently increases soil organic carbon.
Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains can result in larger soil aggregates.
Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains can raise yields in some trials.
Earlier-season incorporation of fresh plant material or crop remains has resulted in higher barley yield and higher grain yield.
Retaining crop residues has been reported to increase microbial biomass.
Retaining crop residues has been reported to reduce water runoff.
Retaining crop residues has been reported to increase water storage.
Retaining crop residues has been reported to reduce soil erosion.
Retaining crop residues has shown mixed effects on soil physical properties.
Retaining crop residues can increase soil organic carbon and nitrogen, sometimes requiring the use of fertilizer.
Retaining crop residues can raise yields, sometimes only in combination with fertilizer and no-tillage practices.
Incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals has been shown to reduce weed growth.
Weed control from incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals can be variable or short-lived.
Incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals has shown mixed effects on pests.
Incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals may inhibit crop growth, an effect that can be mitigated by timing.
The effect on yield from incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals is mixed and depends on the specific crop and controls used.
One study noted that incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals increased profit compared to unweeded controls, but not compared to weeded controls.

question_details.query: What evidence is available from studies in the UK on how soil amendments affect nutrient loss?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Replicated trials from New Zealand and the UK testing nitrification inhibitors reported reduced nitrate losses and nitrous oxide emissions in three of five trials, with one trial finding no effect, and a separate trial found reduced nutrient and soil loss with aluminium sulphate application [909]. Studies from Canada, Spain, the UK and the USA measuring manure applications reported that three randomized, replicated studies found reduced nutrient loss and higher nitrogen levels with farmyard or poultry manure, one study found lower nutrient loss when farmyard manure was applied in winter rather than autumn, and one controlled replicated study detected higher nitrate leaching [911]. Two controlled, replicated trials from Spain and the United Kingdom found that applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure and reduced soil loss but increased nutrient loss in one trial, while molasses additions improved nutrient retention and increased barley yield in another trial [891].
summary_statements: Replicated trials from New Zealand and the UK testing nitrification inhibitors reported reduced nitrate losses and nitrous oxide emissions in three of five trials.
One trial testing nitrification inhibitors found no effect.
A separate trial found reduced nutrient and soil loss with aluminium sulphate application.
Three randomized, replicated studies measuring manure applications found reduced nutrient loss and higher nitrogen levels with farmyard or poultry manure.
One study found lower nutrient loss when farmyard manure was applied in winter rather than in autumn.
One controlled replicated study detected higher nitrate leaching following manure applications.
Two controlled, replicated trials from Spain and the United Kingdom found that applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure and reduced soil loss.
One trial found that applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure increased nutrient loss.
In a separate trial, molasses additions improved nutrient retention and increased barley yield.

question_details.query: How do the effects of cover crops on soil organic matter differ between studies in Europe and the USA?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across arable fields, a meta-analysis and multiple replicated, controlled studies from Italy, Spain, and the USA reported more soil organic matter (mostly measured as carbon) under winter cover crops in some or all comparisons, while one Italian study found inconsistent differences (sometimes more, sometimes less) (1345). In Europe, evidence is mixed: a replicated study from Denmark found increased soil organic carbon under cover crops, but two European studies (including one controlled, replicated trial) found no marked effect on soil organic matter levels; a German trial also found no effect (898; 897). In the USA, several controlled, randomized, replicated studies reported increased soil carbon and nitrogen under cover crops (898), and five replicated, randomized, controlled studies reported more microbial biomass in soils with cover crops (1345). In orchards and vineyards, ten studies from Chile, France, Spain, and the USA found more soil organic matter with ground cover than without in some or all comparisons, and two meta-analyses from Mediterranean climates also found more organic matter with ground cover; two USA studies found similar organic matter when comparing resident vegetation to seeded cover crops (1367).
summary_statements: Across arable fields, a meta-analysis and multiple replicated, controlled studies from Italy, Spain, and the USA reported more soil organic matter under winter cover crops in some or all comparisons.
In studies from Italy, Spain, and the USA, soil organic matter was mostly measured as carbon.
One Italian study found inconsistent differences in soil organic matter, sometimes reporting more and sometimes less under cover crops.
In Europe, evidence regarding the effect of cover crops on soil organic matter is mixed.
A replicated study from Denmark found increased soil organic carbon under cover crops.
Two European studies, including one controlled, replicated trial, found no marked effect of cover crops on soil organic matter levels.
A German trial also found no effect from cover crops on soil organic matter.
In the USA, several controlled, randomized, replicated studies reported increased soil carbon and nitrogen under cover crops.
Five replicated, randomized, controlled studies in the USA reported more microbial biomass in soils with cover crops.
In orchards and vineyards, ten studies from Chile, France, Spain, and the USA found more soil organic matter with ground cover than without in some or all comparisons.
Two meta-analyses from Mediterranean climates also found more organic matter with ground cover in orchards and vineyards.
Two USA studies found similar organic matter levels when comparing resident vegetation to seeded cover crops.

question_details.query: How do the effects of retaining crop residues on-site compare with incorporating plant material brought from elsewhere?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Retaining crop residues on-site has been associated with higher microbial biomass in one replicated study, reduced water runoff, increased water storage, and reduced soil erosion in one review, mixed effects on soil physical properties in one replicated site comparison, higher soil organic carbon and nitrogen in two randomized, replicated trials (one only when fertilizer was also applied), and higher yields in two randomized, replicated trials (one only when combined with fertilizer application and no-tillage) [907]. Incorporating plant material or crop remains (including straw, compost, and fresh plant material) has been associated with increased microbial biomass in one randomized, replicated experiment, improved soil structure in one study but no improvement in anaerobic compacted soils in one before-and-after trial, reduced soil loss in one randomized, replicated study with mixed erosion effects depending on soil type in another, higher soil nitrogen in four replicated studies (with mixed results for processed wastes) and reduced nitrate leaching in one study, higher soil organic carbon across six studies (with larger soil aggregates in one and higher carbon when straw was applied with NPK in one), and higher yields in two trials (barley in Denmark and when residues were incorporated earlier in the season in the Philippines) [910]. Incorporating allelopathic plant remains for weed control showed reductions in weed growth in some studies with variable or short-lived effects in others, mixed effects on pests in one study, inhibited crop growth in two of three studies (mitigable by timing), and yield effects ranging from positive to negative depending on comparison with weeded or unweeded controls, with profit higher than unweeded but not higher than weeded controls in one study [728].
summary_statements: Retaining crop residues on-site has been associated with higher microbial biomass.
Retaining crop residues on-site has been linked to reduced water runoff, increased water storage, and reduced soil erosion.
Retaining crop residues on-site has shown mixed effects on soil physical properties.
Retaining crop residues on-site has been associated with higher soil organic carbon and nitrogen, though one trial showed this effect only when fertilizer was also applied.
Retaining crop residues on-site has been associated with higher yields, though in one trial this was only observed when combined with fertilizer application and no-tillage.
Incorporating plant material or crop remains, including straw, compost, and fresh plant material, has been associated with increased microbial biomass.
Incorporating plant material or crop remains has improved soil structure in some studies but showed no improvement in anaerobic compacted soils.
Incorporating plant material or crop remains has been linked to reduced soil loss, with mixed erosion effects depending on the soil type.
Incorporating plant material or crop remains has been associated with higher soil nitrogen and reduced nitrate leaching, although there were mixed results for processed wastes.

Incorporating plant material or crop remains has been associated with higher soil organic carbon, with one study finding larger soil aggregates and another finding higher carbon when straw was applied with NPK fertilizer.
Incorporating plant material or crop remains has led to higher yields for barley in Denmark and when residues were incorporated earlier in the season in the Philippines.
Incorporating allelopathic plant remains for weed control has shown reductions in weed growth, though the effects were sometimes variable or short-lived.
Incorporating allelopathic plant remains has shown mixed effects on pests.
Incorporating allelopathic plant remains has inhibited crop growth in some studies, an effect that could be mitigated by timing.
The effect of incorporating allelopathic plant remains on yields has ranged from positive to negative, depending on the comparison with weeded or unweeded controls.
Incorporating allelopathic plant remains for weed control resulted in profit that was higher than unweeded controls but not higher than weeded controls in one study.

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and drawbacks of using crop rotation on farms in Canada?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Documented benefits include reduced pest and disease populations in potato systems in at least some years or sites, fewer insecticide treatments needed on rotated plots, and increased yields in some years or with certain rotation crops; one study also reported increased profit (ID 719). Including legumes in rotations increased the number of microbes and diversity of soil animals, including in Canadian trials; including forage crops reduced rainwater runoff and soil loss; crop rotation increased soil organic carbon, particularly with legumes; and several trials found increased soil organic matter, particularly when legumes were included (ID 857). Documented drawbacks or limitations include a study where pest populations increased under rotation, studies showing pest and yield responses that varied depending on the rotation used and other treatments, and a study reporting no effect in some cases (ID 719). One trial found lower soil organic matter with longer rotations (ID 857).
summary_statements: Crop rotation can reduce pest and disease populations in potato systems in at least some years or sites.
Fewer insecticide treatments are needed on plots using crop rotation.
Crop rotation can result in increased yields in some years or with certain rotation crops.
One study reported that crop rotation increased profit.
Including legumes in crop rotations increases the number of microbes and the diversity of soil animals.
Including forage crops in crop rotations reduces rainwater runoff and soil loss.
Crop rotation increases soil organic carbon, particularly when legumes are included.
Several trials found crop rotation increased soil organic matter, particularly when legumes were included.
One study showed that pest populations increased under crop rotation.
Pest and yield responses to crop rotation can vary depending on the specific rotation used and other treatments.
A study reported that crop rotation had no effect in some cases.
One trial found lower soil organic matter with longer crop rotations.

question_details.query: Which soil management practices are most consistently beneficial for increasing soil organic carbon?
What conservation actions have evidence from Canada for improving soil health, particularly biodiversity and organic matter?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Including legumes in crop rotations was associated with increased numbers of microbes and diversity of soil animals in randomized, replicated trials that included Canada; rotations also increased soil organic matter in trials that included Canada, and studies that included Canada reported increased soil organic carbon under rotations, particularly when legumes were included (857). Reduced or no-tillage systems in studies that included Canada found more microbes, more earthworm species, or higher microbe activity, with some studies finding no effect; studies that included Canada found maintained or increased soil organic matter and improved soil structure under reduced tillage; studies that included Canada also found higher soil organic carbon under no/reduced tillage, although one replicated trial from Canada found no effect on soil carbon (906).
summary_statements: Including legumes in crop rotations was associated with increased numbers of microbes.
Including legumes in crop rotations was associated with increased diversity of soil animals.
Crop rotations increased soil organic matter.
Studies reported increased soil organic carbon under crop rotations, particularly when legumes were included.
Reduced or no-tillage systems were found to have more microbes.
Reduced or no-tillage systems were found to have more earthworm species.
Reduced or no-tillage systems were found to have higher microbe activity.
Some studies found no effect from reduced or no-tillage systems.
Reduced tillage was found to maintain or increase soil organic matter.
Reduced tillage was found to improve soil structure.
No-tillage or reduced tillage systems were found to result in higher soil organic carbon.
One replicated trial from Canada found no effect on soil carbon from no-tillage or reduced tillage.

question_details.query: How do the effects of amending soil with municipal wastes compare to using organic processing wastes?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two controlled, replicated trials found that adding municipal compost to semi-arid soils greatly reduced soil loss and water runoff, though another trial reported mixed results for composts and wastes (890). Two controlled, replicated trials (one randomized) on organic processing wastes reported that high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure and reduced soil loss but increased nutrient loss, while adding molasses improved nutrient retention and increased barley (Hordeum vulgare) yield (891). Reported soil types included coarse loamy and sandy loam for municipal wastes (890), and sandy-clay, sandy loam, and silty-clay for organic processing wastes (891).
summary_statements: Two controlled, replicated trials found that adding municipal compost to semi-arid soils greatly reduced soil loss.
Two controlled, replicated trials found that adding municipal compost to semi-arid soils greatly reduced water runoff.
Another trial reported mixed results for the effects of composts and wastes on soil.
High rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure.
High rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure reduced soil loss.
High rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure increased nutrient loss.
Adding molasses improved nutrient retention.
Adding molasses increased barley (Hordeum vulgare) yield.
Reported soil types for municipal waste trials included coarse loamy and sandy loam.
Reported soil types for organic processing waste trials included sandy-clay, sandy loam, and silty-clay.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for actions that reduce nutrient loss from sandy-loam soils?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Applying formulated chemical compounds such as nitrification inhibitors reduced nitrate losses in several trials and aluminium sulphate reduced nutrient and soil loss, although one trial found no effect; studies included sandy loam among the soil types tested [909]. Applying manures or agricultural composts resulted in reduced nutrient loss and higher nitrogen levels in several randomized, replicated studies, though one controlled replicated study reported higher nitrate leaching; soil types included sandy loam [911]. Incorporating fresh plant material or crop remains (e.g., straw) increased soil nitrogen in multiple studies and one study found reduced nitrate leaching with straw incorporation, with soils tested including sandy loam [910]. Growing cover crops when fields are empty improved nutrient retention and one trial reported reduced nitrate leaching, with sandy-loam among the soil types covered [898]. Delaying ploughing until spring reduced nitrate leaching in site comparison studies that included sandy-loam soils [712]. Using a mix of organic and inorganic amendments increased nutrients present in soils in controlled, randomized, replicated trials, with sandy-loam among the soil types covered [902]. Adding mulch increased nutrient levels in one replicated study, with sandy loam among the soils studied [887]. Incorporating leys into crop rotation reduced undesirable nitrogen uptake by grasses on sandy-loam soils [900]. In contrast, a study on generally reducing fertilizer, pesticide or herbicide use found lower nutrient levels and yields in low-input systems on soils including sandy-loam [904].
summary_statements: Applying formulated chemical compounds such as nitrification inhibitors reduced nitrate losses in several trials.
Applying aluminium sulphate reduced nutrient and soil loss, although one trial found no effect.
Studies on formulated chemical compounds included sandy loam among the soil types tested.
Applying manures or agricultural composts resulted in reduced nutrient loss and higher nitrogen levels in several randomized, replicated studies.
One controlled replicated study reported higher nitrate leaching after applying manures or agricultural composts.
The soil types in studies on manures and composts included sandy loam.
Incorporating fresh plant material or crop remains increased soil nitrogen in multiple studies.
One study found reduced nitrate leaching with straw incorporation.
Soils tested for incorporating plant material included sandy loam.
Growing cover crops when fields are empty improved nutrient retention.
One trial reported reduced nitrate leaching from growing cover crops, with sandy-loam among the soil types covered.
Delaying ploughing until spring reduced nitrate leaching in site comparison studies that included sandy-loam soils.
Using a mix of organic and inorganic amendments increased nutrients present in soils in controlled, randomized, replicated trials.
The trials on organic and inorganic amendments included sandy-loam among the soil types covered.
Adding mulch increased nutrient levels in one replicated study where sandy loam was among the soils studied.
Incorporating leys into crop rotation reduced undesirable nitrogen uptake by grasses on sandy-loam soils.
A study on generally reducing fertilizer, pesticide or herbicide use found lower nutrient levels and yields in low-input systems.
The study on low-input systems was conducted on soils including sandy-loam.

question_details.query: What are the effects of incorporating hedgerows or tree lines into agricultural land?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Managing hedgerows for wildlife increased berry yields, plant and invertebrate species diversity or richness, and diversity or abundance of farmland birds in several studies, though some studies found no effects on plant species richness, bumblebee queens, or farmland birds, and management that removed fruit-bearing wood reduced hawthorn berry yield; hedges cut every two years provided more suitable nesting habitat for grey partridge than other regimes (116). Planting or maintaining hedgerows was associated with higher brown hare density in arable sites but not grassland sites in one study, Irish hare numbers did not increase in another, and establishing hedgerows alongside arable land increased small mammal abundance (2383). Intercropping with tree lines (alley cropping) increased the diversity of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi in a sandy-loam context (903). One study found no difference in the number of flower species in hedgerows compared to weedy field edges, while implementation comparisons reported more plant species in narrow than wide hedgerows, higher plant cover in younger than older hedgerows, and higher cover of exotic plants than native plants in young hedgerows but not in old hedgerows (1415).
summary_statements: Managing hedgerows for wildlife increased berry yields.
Managing hedgerows for wildlife increased plant and invertebrate species diversity or richness.
Managing hedgerows for wildlife increased the diversity or abundance of farmland birds in several studies.
Some studies found that managing hedgerows had no effects on plant species richness, bumblebee queens, or farmland birds.
Management that removed fruit-bearing wood reduced hawthorn berry yield.
Hedges cut every two years provided more suitable nesting habitat for grey partridge than other cutting regimes.
Planting or maintaining hedgerows was associated with higher brown hare density in arable sites.
Planting or maintaining hedgerows was not associated with higher brown hare density in grassland sites.
A study found that Irish hare numbers did not increase after hedgerows were established.
Establishing hedgerows alongside arable land increased small mammal abundance.
Intercropping with tree lines, known as alley cropping, increased the diversity of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi in a sandy-loam context.
One study found no difference in the number of flower species in hedgerows compared to weedy field edges.
Implementation comparisons reported more plant species in narrow hedgerows than in wide hedgerows.
Implementation comparisons reported higher plant cover in younger hedgerows than in older hedgerows.
Young hedgerows had a higher cover of exotic plants than native plants.
Old hedgerows did not have a higher cover of exotic plants than native plants.

question_details.query: What are the effects of reducing physical disturbance from machinery on agricultural soils?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence on reducing physical disturbance via reduced tillage and controlling machinery traffic shows: Reduced tillage often increases soil organic carbon and can maintain or increase soil organic matter and improve soil structure, though some studies report no effect or higher compaction under reduced tillage [906]. Reduced tillage frequently reduces soil loss and runoff, but no-tillage can increase soil loss if there is no crop cover [906]. Effects on soil biota are mixed: several studies found more microbes, more earthworm species, or higher microbial activity under reduced tillage, while others found no effect [906]. Yield responses are mixed, with reports of lower, higher (with subsoiling), or no change in yield depending on context [906]. Controlling machinery traffic can increase the number of soil pores, reduce compaction, reduce runoff, and increase water infiltration; some studies also found increased yields under controlled traffic [899]. Biological responses to traffic control are mixed, with one study finding higher numbers and bacterial activity under controlled traffic and another finding higher microbial biomass when traffic was not controlled [899].
summary_statements: Reduced tillage often increases soil organic carbon.
Reduced tillage can maintain or increase soil organic matter.
Reduced tillage can improve soil structure.
Some studies report no effect or higher compaction under reduced tillage.
Reduced tillage frequently reduces soil loss and runoff.
No-tillage can increase soil loss if there is no crop cover.
The effects of reduced tillage on soil biota are mixed.
Several studies found more microbes under reduced tillage.
Several studies found more earthworm species under reduced tillage.
Several studies found higher microbial activity under reduced tillage.
Some studies found no effect on soil biota from reduced tillage.
Yield responses to reduced tillage are mixed.
Reports indicate reduced tillage can result in lower, higher (with subsoiling), or no change in yield depending on the context.
Controlling machinery traffic can increase the number of soil pores.
Controlling machinery traffic can reduce compaction.
Controlling machinery traffic can reduce runoff.
Controlling machinery traffic can increase water infiltration.
Some studies found increased yields under controlled machinery traffic.
Biological responses to controlling machinery traffic are mixed.
One study found higher numbers of biota and higher bacterial activity under controlled machinery traffic.
Another study found higher microbial biomass when machinery traffic was not controlled.

question_details.query: On sandy loam soils, how do the effects of amending with municipal waste compost compare to amending with organic processing waste composts?

summary_details.relevant_summary: On sandy loam soils, municipal waste compost reduced soil loss and water runoff in semi-arid settings, based on controlled, replicated trials in Spain and the UK (soil types covered included sandy loam) [890]. In comparison, organic processing waste composts showed that high application rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure and reduced soil loss but also increased nutrient loss; additionally, adding molasses improved nutrient retention and increased barley yield, with evidence from controlled, replicated trials in Spain and the UK (soil types covered included sandy loam) [891].
summary_statements: On sandy loam soils, municipal waste compost reduced soil loss and water runoff in semi-arid settings.
High application rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure on sandy loam soils.
High application rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure reduced soil loss on sandy loam soils.
High application rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure also increased nutrient loss on sandy loam soils.
Adding molasses to organic processing waste composts improved nutrient retention on sandy loam soils.
Adding molasses to organic processing waste composts increased barley yield on sandy loam soils.

question_details.query: What does the evidence from the USA indicate about the effect of different agricultural practices on crop yields?
Besides using crop rotation, what other actions can increase the biodiversity of soil organisms?
